questions.content: Which are true? (Choose all that apply.)

answers.content: "X extends Y" is correct if and only if X is a class and Y is an interface.
"X extends Y" is correct if and only if X is an interface and Y is a class.
"X extends Y" is correct if X and Y are either both classes or both interfaces.
"X extends Y" is correct for all combinations of X and Y being classes and/or interfaces.

questions.content: You're designing a new online board game in which ```Floozels``` are a type of ```Jammers, Jammers``` can have ```Quizels, Quizels``` are a type of ```Klakker```, and ```Floozels``` can have several ```Floozets```. Which of the following fragments represent this design? (Choose all that apply.)

answers.content: It is not possible to know
An exception is thrown at runtime

questions.content:
Given:
    ```
    public class Literally {
      public static void main(String[] args) {
        int i1 = 1_000;      // line A
        int i2 = 10_00;      // line B
        int i3 = _10_000;    // line C
        int i4 = 0b101010;   // line D
        int i5 = 0B10_1010;  // line E
        int i6 = 0x2_a;      // line F
      } 
    }
    ```
    Which lines WILL NOT compile? (Choose all that apply.)

questions.content: Which are true? (Choose all that apply.)

It is appropriate to catch and handle assertion errors
It is NOT appropriate to use assertions to validate command-line arguments

It is NOT appropriate for assertions to change a program's state

questions.content:
Given three resource bundles and a Java class:
```
Train_en_US.properties: train=subway
Train_en_UK.properties: train=underground
Train_en.properties: ride = ride

1: public class ChooChoo {
2:   public static void main(String[] args) {                
3:     Locale.setDefault(new Locale("en", "US"));            
4:     ResourceBundle rb = ResourceBundle.getBundle("Train", 
5:       new Locale("en", "US"));                            
6:     System.out.print(rb.getString("ride")                 
         + " " + rb.getString("train"));                     
7    } 
8: }
```      
Which of the following, when made independently, 
will change the output to "ride underground"? 
(Choose all that apply.)

answers.content: The first line of output is ```abc abc true```
The first line of output is ```abc abc false```
The first line of output is ```abcd abc false```
The second line of output is ```abcd abc false```
The second line of output is ```abcd abcd true```
The second line of output is ```abcd abcd false```
The code compiles and runs without exception
The invocation of parse() must be placed within a try/catch block
An Exception is thrown at runtime

questions.content:
Which of the following creates a Path object pointing
 to ```c:/temp/exam```? (Choose all that apply.)

Given a directory tree at the root of the C: 
drive and the fact that no other files exist:
```
dir x - |
..........| - dir y
..........| - file a
```      
and these two paths:
```
Path one = Paths.get("c:/x");
Path two = Paths.get("c:/x/y/a");
```
Which of the following statements prints out: 
y/a ?

Given the following statements:
I. A nonempty directory can usually be deleted using
 Files.delete
II. A nonempty directory can usually be moved using
 Files.move
III. A nonempty directory can usually be copied using 
 Files.copy
Which of the following is true?

Given:
```
new File("c:/temp/test.txt").delete();
```
How would you write this line of code using 
Java 7 APIs?
Which of the following are true? (Choose all that apply.)

answers.content: The ```class AbstractFileAttributes``` applies to all operating systems
The ```class BasicFileAttributes``` applies to all operating systems
The ```class DosFileAttributes``` applies to Windows-based operating systems
The ```class WindowsFileAttributes``` applies to Windows-based operating systems
The ```class PosixFileAttributes``` applies to all Linux/UNIX-based operating systems
The ```class UnixFileAttributes``` applies to all Linux/UNIX-based operating systems

questions.content:
Given a partial directory tree:
        dir x - |
        ..........| - dir y
        ..........| - file a
In what order can the following methods be called 
if walking the directory tree from x? 
(Choose all that apply.)

I:preVisitDirectory x 
II:preVisitDirectory x/y 
III:postVisitDirectory x/y 
IV:postVisitDirectory x
V:visitFile x/a

Assume all the files referenced by these paths exist: 
```
Path a = Paths.get("c:/temp/dir/a.txt");
Path b = Paths.get("c:/temp/dir/subdir/b.txt");
```
What is the correct string to pass to PathMatcher 
to match both these files?

answers.content: Code compiles but does not output anything
Does not compile because DirectoryStream comes from FileSystems, not Files
Does not compile for another reason

questions.content:
Given a partial directory tree:
        dir x - |
        ..........| - dir y
        ..........| -file a
and given that a valid Path object, dir, 
points to x, and given this snippet: 
```
WatchKey key = dir.register(watcher, ENTRY_CREATE);
```
If a WatchService is set using the given WatchKey, 
what would be the result if a file is added todir y?

answers.content: A notice related to dir x is issued
A notice related to dir y is issued
Notices for both dir x and dir y are given
The behavior depends on the underlying operating system
